From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> Multiple possible problems:
> 1. Loss of XML comments
>    Are they part of the infoset?
> 2. Loss of whitespace information
> 3. Loss of document-checksum abilities
> If I PUT a PGP-signed XML document, absent some
> convention about signing XML-infosets, I think we
> need to get back an identical document in order
> to verify my signature.
>
> As a general matter, would you want to PUT a
> MSWord6 document and GET a MSWord7 document?

Not if I couldn't read it with MSWord6.  Any of the items listed above all
fall under "can I use the GET version exactly like I use the PUT version?"
If you don't care about comments, then it doesn't matter whether they are
stripped or not.  It all depends on your application.  Restricting PUT in
ways that are more of a hinderance than a help to some applications doesn't
seem right.  Of course, a given application can always be more restricitve
if desired, but those same restrictions should not be forced on all
applications (imho).

Frankly, I have found little practical use for PUT.  It may be because it's
too limiting.  It may be because it's too difficult to use in some cases
(such as updating container resources).  In the end, about the only thing
that it seems safe to use it for is creation of a new resource when you have
control over the URI space.  And even then, issues such as the one being
discussed come up.

PUT just can't win, no matter how hard it tries...
